title: Construction of the Notre-Dame de Fourvière basilica
description: On Lyon's Fourvière hill, the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière is one of the city's major architectural landmarks. Built after the Franco-Prussian war, it is a symbol of religious devotion and national resistance. With its neo-Byzantine style, it overlooks Lyon and attracts thousands of visitors every year. It also symbolizes the rise of the Catholic Church in France at the time.

title: Glières plateau
description: In 1944, the Glières plateau became an emblematic site of the French resistance against Nazi occupation. Resistance fighters grouped on the plateau carried out sabotage actions against German forces. The Battle of Glières was one of the Resistance's first major offensives, symbolizing their courage and determination. This episode strengthened the fight for the liberation of France and is commemorated today as a symbol of the Resistance.

title: First ascent of Mont Blanc
description: The first ascent of Mont Blanc by Jacques Balmat and Michel-Gabriel Paccard marked a milestone in the history of mountaineering. This success inspired a wave of exploration of Europe's mountains. The ascent of Mont Blanc, the highest peak in the Alps, also marked the beginning of alpine tourism and contributed to the international renown of the Chamonix region. Today, Mont Blanc is a symbol of the challenges of mountaineering and the natural beauty of the Alps.

title: Day of the Tiles
description: The Day of the Tiles was an event that took place in the French town of Grenoble on 7 June 1788. It was one of the first disturbances preceding the French Revolution and is credited by a few historians as its start.

title: Évian Accords
description: The Évian Accords were a set of peace treaties signed on 18 March 1962 in Évian-les-Bains, France, by France and the Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic, the government-in-exile of FLN (Front de Libération Nationale), which sought Algeria's independence from France. The Accords ended the 1954–1962 Algerian War with a formal cease-fire proclaimed for 19 March and formalized the status of Algeria as an independent nation and the idea of cooperative exchanges between the two countries.

title: Council of Clermont
description: The Council of Clermont was a mixed synod of ecclesiastics and laymen of the Catholic Church, called by Pope Urban II and held from 17 to 27 November 1095 at Clermont, Auvergne, at the time part of the Duchy of Aquitaine.[1][2]

title: Canut revolts
description: The Canut revolts is the collective name for the major revolts by Lyonnais silk workers which occurred in 1831 and 1834. They were among the first well-defined worker uprisings of the period known as the Industrial Revolution. The First Canut revolt in 1831 was provoked by a bad economy and a resultant drop in silk prices, which caused a drop in workers' wages. The Second Canut revolt in 1834 occurred in a prosperous economy that had caused a surge in workers' wages.

title: The Lumière brothers invent filmmaking
description: The Lumière brothers, Auguste Lumière and Louis Jean Lumière, were French manufacturers of photography equipment, best known for their Cinématographe motion picture system and the short films they produced between 1895 and 1905, which places them among the earliest filmmakers.

title: Winter Olympics
description: The 1992 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XVI Olympic Winter Games, were a winter multi-sport event held from 8 to 23 February 1992 in and around Albertville. Albertville won the bid to host the Winter Olympics in 1986, beating Sofia, Falun, Lillehammer, Cortina d'Ampezzo, Anchorage, and Berchtesgaden. This games was the first of two consecutive Olympic games to be held in Western Europe, preceding the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.

title: German occupation during World War II
description: Following France's defeat in June 1940, the Germans occupied the northern part of France militarily, and then, from November 1942, the whole of France. While the Vichy government was nominally in charge of all of France, the military administration in the occupied zone was a de facto Nazi dictatorship, where the actual sovereignty of the French government was seriously limited.
